GameEventAction.Description: This world was once a thriving research center for the Ackdarian Technocracy. Its facilities will surely improve our research efforts. It is not overly optimistic to pronounce that all Ackdarians everywhere are on the cusp of a new golden age.
An Experimental Flux Drive

We have discovered Ackdara, the ancient Ackdarian homeworld. This was a pristine ocean planet until the Cataclysm. Despite the massive damage to this world, we have discovered some important artifacts. Notable among these is the Pearl of the Deep, an ancient Ucantium Pearl of perfect quality and extraordinary size.
We've discovered the Constitution Crystal, a crystalline storage device containing possibly the only surviving original copy of the Constitution of the ancient Freedom Alliance.

GameEvent.Name: Ancient Capital Chain Fortress World (Non Ackdarian)

GameEventAction.Description: This massive spaceport is unlike anything we have been able to construct and unlike anything we have encountered in our travels. Studying it will enable us to improve our spaceports as well as our ship design technology.

GameEvent.Name: Ancient Capital Chain High-Tech World (Non Ackdarian)

GameEventAction.Description: This world was once a thriving research center for the Ackdarian Technocracy. Having this world and the remnants of its facilities in our possession will surely improve our own research efforts.
An Experimental Flux Drive

We have discovered a colonizable planet, one that bears the scars of battle! Preliminary surveys show signs of ancient bombardment and massive destruction. Surface ruins appear to be of Mortalen design, which suggest our ancestors fought bravely here. We must investigate and learn more.

It is much as we thought. On the surface we have found evidence of a fierce ground battle in which Mortalens gloriously held out against we believe to be a much larger force of insectoid aliens. All evidence points to an impossible battle, and yet our ancestors fought as only Mortalens can, to the last soldier, pursuing the dream of victory and the glory of combat. It is an honor to witness the remnants of such bravery.
And yet there is also much that puzzles us. The planetary buildings of the era were destroyed around the time of the battle, but not by the battle itself. There is evidence of planet-wide seismic activity. This raises interesting questions. Perhaps we will discover answers on other worlds.
We have also found a badly damaged Planetary Bastion facility, which we can study to unlock its secrets. Doing so will aid us in our weapons research.
We have discovered what appears to be a crashed alien troop transport. It would be wise to investigate the planet further for signs of potential enemies.

Further investigation of the planet revealed an underground colony of the insectoid aliens. These disgusting creatures are most likely descended from survivors of the troop transport crash.
These aliens have proved themselves vile not only in appearance, but also in behavior. They launched a dishonorable assault upon our surface exploration team. The Mortalen explorers were taken by surprise in a cowardly ambush, and though they fought bravely, the were outnumbered and ultimately overcome. We must avenge them and answer blood with blood.
Ancient History
Further investigation of the planet revealed an underground colony of the insectoid aliens. They are most likely descended from survivors of the troop transport crash.

After glorious conquest, and with the planet now under our control, we have been able to complete our investigation of the alien colony.
Our first priority has been to study the ancient troop transport, which appears to be of an almost organic insectoid design. We have also investigated the enormous underground hives these aliens built and inhabited. They lived as though they were no better than beasts! Still, there is a certain complexity of design, and studying their primitive techniques will advance our own construction research.
We have been unable to salvage any data or logs, but we have learned these aliens were known as the "Boskara." A study of their language and legends reveal stories describing a formidable species part reptilian and part mammalian whom they regarded as their rivals and enemies. It is clear they speak of the Mortalen, whom they were wise to respect and fear. It is a lesson this colony would have been wise to heed.

In the {1} system, we have found an old, badly damaged orbital base and the remains of a small fleet. The base is broadcasting a warning in an ancient Mortalen dialect. If we approach, we will be attacked.
We have attempted to communicate that we are Mortalen and must not be regarded as an enemy, but the base does not respond. Our only remaining options are to capture or destroy it.
In the {1} system, we have found an old, badly damaged orbital base and the remains of a small fleet. The base is broadcasting a message in an alien language, which we believe to be a warning.

Glorious battle has led to victory. The Mortalen of the past were great, but their automated base was no match for living, breathing warriors.
By examining the remains of the station, we have been able to glean some secrets of ancient Mortalen technology and improve our understanding of the ancient Mortalen language. These are the rewards of conquest.

By examining the remains of the station, we have determined that it once belonged to the Mortalen. From the few intact logs, we have been able to glean some secrets of ancient Mortalen technology as well learn the Mortalen language.

The logs on the captured base indicate it belonged to the ancient Mortalen Empire. The ships stationed here were charged with protecting the Mortalen core worlds from an enemy known as the Shaktur Axis.
The final logs indicate that the losses from a long battle had been severe among the Mortalen fleet and army. This base had been only lightly crewed, relying mostly on automation and a newly-developed artificial intelligence. This seems like a foolish decision, for machines are a poor substitute for a true Mortalen.
Among the data we have found some interesting information that will advance our technology. Careful study of the logs have improved our understanding of the ancient Mortalen language.

The logs on the captured base indicate it belonged to the ancient Mortalen Empire. The ships stationed here were charged with protecting the Mortalen core worlds from an enemy known as the Shaktur Axis.
The final logs indicate that the losses from a long battle had been severe among the Mortalen fleet and army. This base had been only lightly crewed, relying mostly on automation and a newly-developed artificial intelligence.

We have encountered an independent world in the {1} system, populated by several different alien species.
They appear to recognize our kind, though they are reluctant to say how. They display evident and appropriate fear of us, which suggests they have fought Mortalen in the past and know they cannot stand against us. Such is their eagerness to avoid conflict that they have offered to bribe us with what they claim is an ancient relic of our species. They will give it to us in exchange for peace and agreement that we will not make any more inquiries about their history.
Should we accept the artifact, or refuse and push for more information?

These craven inferiors will pay any price to avoid conflict with the Mortalen. We would crush them, so they show wisdom if not honor. In exchange for our forbearance, they have given us a relic known as the "Glaive of Mor," and they have aided us in some of our technological research. They remain distrustful of us, but their opinions are of little interest to us.
Ancient History

We have refused their offer, and now this mix of alien flotsam dare to speak boldly to us. They say that their ancestors were once slaves to the Mortalen, forced to serve in the mines on this world. Then, according to their legends, came a great Cataclysm that created global chaos. The slaves broke free of their chains and rose up against their Mortalen masters.
We must assume that the circumstances of this Cataclysm left many more aliens than Mortalen alive. How else to explain that the wretched slaves defeated the Mortalen?
Now they strike a defiant tone, but if they face the Mortalen in battle again, it is doubtful they will fare as well as their forebears.
Ancient History

We have encountered an independent world in the {1} system, populated by several species of aliens.
They say their ancestors were once enslaved by a species of brutal reptilian warriors. This was during a time of a great galactic war, and as that war came to an end, the slaves overthrew their masters. Once free, they joined together to build a new society where they live in peace and freedom.
On this world we have discovered what appear to be the ruins of an ancient Mortalen cloning facility. Should we investigate?

We have made a discovery both interesting and troubling. Further exploration has revealed that this planet was once dedicated to the creation of highly modified Mortalen clone troops. The many remains suggest many battles were once fought between the ancient Mortalen and some of the clones.
A small number of stasis pods are still functioning at the facility, and enhanced Mortalen clones seem to be alive within. If these clones were conscious in the past, they could provide important information about the ancient Mortalen Empire. Yet some clones appear to have made war against their creators, suggesting the clones could be dangerous.
Should we dissect the clones, or bring their pods to a colony and attempt to revive them there?

The ancient clones are truly remarkable. It seems they possess redundant internal organs, giving them the ability to survive otherwise fatal injuries and quickly recover from non-fatal wounds. What glorious warriors they must have been! The knowledge we gained from the study of these subjects will greatly enhance our own cloning research.
Within the facility we have also learned the location of the ancient Mortalen homeworld.

When first revived, the enhanced clones were weak and compliant, and our language experts were able to decipher most of their ancient dialect, though they had little to say.
Perhaps they are not very intelligent. They are, however, physically remarkable. Our physicians revealed that they possess redundant internal organs, giving them the ability to survive otherwise fatal injuries and quickly recover from non-fatal wounds. Examining them has yielded a much insight into chimera cloning.
Conversation yielded far less. The clones will answer direct questions, but seem unable or unwilling to provide information spontaneously. Through a series of directed questions, they have revealed the location of our ancient homeworld, and the clones have also provided the location of an old shipyard.
Perhaps, in time, they could have told us more. Unfortunately, the clones began to grow aggressive. They overwhelmed their guards and began a rampage through the colony. They proved to be worthy adversaries, using ingenious tactics to defeat more numerous and better armed opponents. Their incredible capabilities made each clone more than a match for multiple Mortalen soldiers. In the end, the clones were destroyed, but not before they did significant damage and produced numerous casualties among the population
Even more alarming, there are signs that the clones may have carried a virus, which has begun spreading. Scientists are calling it the Genetic Scrambling Virus.

Our exploration has revealed that this planet was once dedicated to the creation of highly modified clone troops. The many remains suggest many battles were once fought between the ancient Mortalen and the clones.
A small number of stasis pods are still functioning at the facility, and enhanced Mortalen clones seem to be alive within.
Should we dissect the clones, or bring their pods to a colony and attempt to revive them there?

The ancient clones are truly remarkable. It seems they possess redundant internal organs, giving them the ability to survive otherwise fatal injuries and quickly recover from non-fatal wounds. The knowledge we gained from the study of these subjects will greatly enhance our own cloning research.
Within the facility we have also learned the location of the ancient Mortalen homeworld.

In retrospect, reviving ancient warrior clones may not have been the wisest decision.
When first awakened, the clones were weak and compliant, though they had little to say. Our physicians revealed that they possess redundant internal organs, giving them the ability to survive otherwise fatal injuries and quickly recover from non-fatal wounds. Examining them has yielded a much insight into chimera cloning.
Soon the clones began to grow aggressive. They overwhelmed their guards and began a rampage through the colony, using ingenious tactics to defeat more numerous and better armed opponents. In the end, the clones were destroyed, but not before they did significant damage and produced numerous casualties among the population
Even more alarming, there are signs that the clones may have carried a virus, which has begun spreading. Scientists are calling it the Genetic Scrambling Virus.

Evidence obtained from the wreckage indicates that as the Shakturi war dragged on, our ancestors could not meet the demand for ship personnel or troops. So many had already died honorably in battle, and yet the war could not be abandoned. This location was dedicated to building almost entirely automated ships, despite our ancestors' disdain for robots, AI, and synthetics.
Clearly this experiment was not successful. We have encountered evidence that some of the debris in orbit derives from battles between Mortalen ships, perhaps indicating that the automated vessels malfunctioned and attacked a small Mortalen contingent. There is additional information that the ship in orbit bombarded the planet surface.
Data in some of the wreckage indicates the location of the Ancient Mortalen homeworld.

In orbit around this world, we've discovered a junkyard and an ancient Mortalen battleship.
The ship initially appeared to be abandoned, but then it suddenly powered up and transmitted a brief burst of data.

Evidence obtained from the wreckage indicates that as the Shakturi war dragged on, the Mortalen Empire could not meet the demand for ship personnel or troops. This location was dedicated to building almost entirely automated ships, despite the Mortalen dislike of robots, AI, and synthetics.
Clearly this experiment was not successful. We have encountered evidence that some of the debris in orbit derives from battles between Mortalen ships, perhaps indicating that the automated vessels malfunctioned and attacked the Mortalen themselves. There is additional information that ship in orbit bombarded the planet surface.
Data in some of the wreckage indicates the location of the Ancient Mortalen homeworld.

In orbit around this world, we've discovered a junkyard and an ancient Mortalen battleship.
The ship initially appeared to be abandoned, but then it suddenly powered up and transmitted a brief burst of data.

GeneratedItemEventNames.string: Ancient Capital Chain Capital World (Non Mortalen)

GameEventAction.Description:
We have discovered what is surely the lost homeworld of the Mortalen. We had hoped this would be a joyous occasion, but instead it is a time of mourning. The world is ruined, devastated by the ancient Cataclysm.
Records recovered from the ruins reveal the glorious exploits of the Mortalen Empire, which refused to bow to either side in the war. Our ancestors could see no honor in joining with Shakturi, nor with demeaning themselves by fighting alongside the Alliance. Instead, they fought both, intent on claiming victory only for themselves.
And how close they came. We can only imagine such battles! Against impossible odds, the Mortalen won battle after battle. But such victories were costly, and the Mortalen suffered such losses that they had no choice but turn to cloning and synthetics, lest they be overwhelmed.
On the verge of total defeat, our ancestors seem to have done something remarkable: they captured a Shakturi doomsday weapon, which surely would have turned the tide of the war were it not for the Cataclysm. Such a weapon now, in our hands, would make us unstoppable. Planetary records reveal the weapon's last known coordinates...

After a thorough exploration of our ancient homeworld, we have discovered a fascinating relic, the ancient artifact called the Spear of the First King. This weapon, forged long ago and used by great heroes, is a symbol of all things heroic and Mortalen. It will be a symbol of our continuing glory.
We have discovered an experimental planetary bombardment weapon.

GeneratedItemEventNames.string: Ancient Capital Chain Fortress World (Non Mortalen)

GameEventAction.Description:
On this ancient fortress world, we have discovered a planetary torpedo-launcher facility. Studying it will help us to unlock its secrets and achieve the greatness of our forebears.
Within the facility we have discovered a single remaining experimental torpedo, our scientists believe it could be a weapon of unparalleled power!

GameEvent.Name: Ancient Capital Chain Military HQ World (Mortalen)

GeneratedItemEventNames.string: Ancient Capital Chain Military HQ World (Non Mortalen)

GameEventAction.Description: This world was once the site of a great Mortalen military academy. In its wreckage, we have found details of an experimental stellar armor. This is knowledge we can use to achieve unimagined honor and glory.

GameEvent.Name: Ancient Capital Chain Capital World (Non Mortalen)

GameEventAction.Description:
We have discovered the ancient homeworld of the Mortalens. The world is destroyed, devastated by the ancient Cataclysm.
Records recovered from the ruins reveal that the Mortalen Empire refused to side with either faction and instead made war against both the Shakturi Axis and the Freedom Alliance. If their records can be trusted, they fared remarkably well, winning battle after battle. Nevertheless, their victories came at a high price. The Mortalen lost so many troops that had they no choice but turn to cloning and synthetics, lest they be overwhelmed.

After a thorough exploration of the Mortalen homeworld, we have discovered a fascinating relic, the ancient artifact called the Spear of the First King. This weapon, forged long ago and used by the warriors of this world. It is a meaningful symbol to the Mortalen, but it will be of use to us as well.
We have discovered an experimental planetary bombardment weapon.

GameEvent.Name: Ancient Capital Chain Fortress World (Non Mortalen)

GameEventAction.Description: On this ancient fortress world, we have discovered a planetary torpedo-launcher facility. Studying it will help us to unlock its secrets and claim its power for ourselves.

GameEvent.Name: Ancient Capital Chain Military HQ World (Non Mortalen)

GameEventAction.Description: This world was once the site of a Mortalen military academy. In its wreckage, we have found details of an experimental stellar armor. This is knowledge that will make us even more formidable.

Here, too, the Boskara spread their dominion. Our kind once had a base on the surface. We have found the wreckage of ancient landing pods, likely from the transport in orbit. No life remains, but there is still much to be learned here.

Remarkable! Curious! An ancient, automated station, clearly of Boskara design. And a troop transport, ours for the taking. We have begun to walk in the paths of those who came before us. We must pacify this station, make use of what we find. We shall expand, consume, take. In so doing, we shall discover what the past has to teach us.

So much time, so much damage, but even so, here is lost knowledge. Here are clues to the Boskara past. This station, this system, was once on the very fringes of Boskara space. The base was used for communicating with aliens called Shakturi. They were our allies, perhaps? Our minions? Did these Shakturi quake when they heard the name Boskara? Likely so, for we have learned that other enslaved beings fought alongside the Boskara and against something called the "Freedom Alliance." Pathetic name! Weak and repulsive creatures known as "Humans" and "Ackdarians" dared to oppose the Boskara and their Shakturi minions. No doubt they were wiped out and exist no more.

The station is utterly destroyed, as are all things that oppose the Boskara tide. Nevertheless, our clever scientists were able to recover some bits of data. This place was once a border monitoring station for the ancient Boskara Supremacy. Discovery! Records of communication with beings called Shakturi. No doubt our minions! Our ancestor's dominion was truly vast. The ease with which we defeated their automated defenses prove we shall match their power and then exceed it.

This world has a low population of inhabitants, primitive beings who call themselves Ackdarians. Our kind is known to them. "In our legends we have heard tales of ancient conquerors, ruthless and bloodthirsty warriors called the Boskara. Are you these same Boskara?"

We need fear no one nor hide conceal our identity. Why should we not admit to being Boskara, the same great culture that once conquered them? "Our legends tell stories of your infinite cruelty and malice," they tell us. "We can never forget what you did, and we will never see you as anything but our enemies." So be it!
We remember your past crimes.

"Your resemblance to the Boskara of our legends is uncanny, but we will take you at your word. For now. Perhaps we can coexist together. We shall judge you by your actions, though we will watch you closely."
We are suspicious of you!

It was always inevitable. We encountered them, and so we fought them. We fought them, and so we conquered them. The Boskara consume. Belarion is now ours, and we have scoured it for information about our own past. We have learned that our civilization was called the Boskara Supremacy, and we were unmatched in a galaxy teaming with life. None dared stand against us, and those who did, fell. Our allies, the Shakturi, it seems were feared as well. Perhaps they were feared almost as much as we were. It is difficult to be certain, but their reputation for cruelty was unmatched. We were wise to make them our puppets.

We've found a sparsely inhabited world. The inhabitants are the Humans. These beings have a memory of the Boskara, who once conquered their planet and turned its inhabitants into slaves. "You look much like these conquerors of old," {0}'s representative tells our diplomats. "Could it be you are the same species?"

"We are indeed!" we tell these inferior beings. "We take. We consume. We conquer." They respond by telling us there can never be peace between our cultures. We suspect they little understand how true that is.
We remember your past crimes.

It is better to deceive them for now. If we conquer them, it will be at the time of our choosing. "It is strange how much you look like the images of Boskara that appear in our ancient texts," their diplomat says, "but appearances can be deceiving. We shall judge you based on what you do, not how you appear." It will be difficult to maintain this ruse forever. For now, it suits our purposes.
We are suspicious of you!

Now that their world is ours, we have sorted through their records, seeking to learn what we can of the Boskara Supremacy and its domination of the old order. It seems our Shakturi allies were regarded as terrifying, perhaps even more terrifying than the Boskara themselves. They had many subordinate allies. Other hivemind beings. It is remarkable that our ancestors did not put these Shakturi in their proper place. Perhaps they did. Perhaps we will learn that once we took all we wished from the Shakturi, we added them to the list of our victims.

Here is a world that our ancestor conquered long ago. The inhabitants, these Teekans, speak of their ancient master, the Boskara, who enslaved their people and massacred their populations. As they were once ruled by the Boskara supremacy, they want to know if we are the same species as their old masters.

"You may be sure we are Boskara!" we tell these inferior beings. "Why should we deny our nature or hide in shadows like inferior beings?" This declaration is met by a terse end of communication. It seems these beings want nothing more to do with us.
We remember your past crimes.

"We are certainly not these conquerors you dread," our diplomats tell the inhabitants of Foralis. "No, that is not us." It is not entirely clear if they believe us. They seem cautious. Perhaps we can win them over in time. If not, there are other means of dealing with intractable worlds.
We are suspicious of you!

An insignificant world, inhabited by weaklings, falls before the Boskara. These beings were nothing, but their history tells much about the mysterious era of the Boskara Supremacy. Foralis was conquered by a fleet of Boskara ships, and yet the records seem to suggest that this happened at the request of the Shakturi. Records say "orders," but sure that is a mistake. No power could have commanded the Boskara Supremacy. Even so, these Shakturi must have been powerful and impressive for the Boskara of the day to take suggestions from them. Another fascinating piece of history is revealed!

During the time of the Boskara Supremacy, our people made this world our own. Now, we stumble upon it anew, and yet we are not entirely forgotten. Like other words the Boskara dominated in ancient times, these beings have long memories, and their legends tell of stories of their conquerors. And as with those other worlds, there is no denying we resemble the species that so long ago took this world and enslaved its people. "That species was called the Boskara," their diplomat says. "Is that what you are called?"

"We are indeed the Boskara," we tell them. "We are the proud hatchlings of those long-ago warriors, and we are born anew to conquer and to make the galaxy our own." Communication with Dubat ends there. It seems they have no more to say to us.
We remember your past crimes.

There is no need to alarm the inhabitants of Dubat. The day may come when we wish to take this world as our own, but we will bide our time and strike only when we are ready. "We are not these Boskara of whom you speak," we tell them. "Ours is another species. You have no need to be alarmed."
We are suspicious of you!

This world is ours to do with as we please! We have searched through the rubble, examined their blasted and smoking databanks, seeking to learn what we can about the Boskara of ancient times. Together with the Shakturi, the Boskara Supremacy engulphed this world, toppling its cities, and enslaving its people. Many were shipped to the Shakturi, whose young fed upon the prisoners.

GeneratedItemEventNames.string: Investigate Ancient Boskara Military Base (Non Boskara)

GameEvent.Name: Investigate Ancient Boskara Military Base (Non Boskara)

GameEventAction.Description: This ancient world is dotted with blasted ruins, almost certainly military in nature. Preliminary scans suggest there may be vast underground complexes honeycombing the entire world. It is entirely possible that automated defenses may still be active. Proceeding with caution is advisable.

This colony once belonged to the Ancient Boskara, serving as a massive, planet-wide military base. Most of it lies in ruins, but we were able to learn something of their lost technology from the damaged databanks.

Ancient world. Many mysteries. Surface is dotted with blasted ruins, once likely military outposts. Such a mighty fortress! Investigation teams discover ruins containing entrances to vast underground complexes. Vast and sprawling. Chambers spread through much of the planet. Entire world dedicated to training troops, researching and building weapons. Great center of military matters. Another glorious achievement of the ancient Boskara Supremacy!

Our explorers continue to explore the ruins. These facilities are like an endless nest, nearly endless, descending level after level, kilometers deep into the surface of this world. More than just training and research! Also breeding facilities to produce warriors. Remnants of armor and weaponry suggest many warriors not Boskara. Insectoid, yes, but not of our kind. Were Shakturi insectoid like us? Perhaps that is why we allowed them so much power within our Supremacy.

Our explorers discover more! Have uncovered what could be entrance to planetary command center. Partially buried, difficult to access. Protected by automated sentries. We must learn more about this facility.
Which division should we allocate to attempt access?

Boskara forces have stormed defensive perimeter! Weapons fire. Much damage, Defensive sentries fall before unstoppable Boskara advance.
Ancient logs reviewed. This base did indeed belong to the ancient Boskara Supremacy and its partners, the Shaktur Axis! Interesting speculations. Shakturi likely not mere subordinates but a separate, impressive power. With Boskara, Shakturi fought newly identified ancient foe: Freedom Alliance. Opposing power appears to wished to test strength against Boskura might. Interesting fragments in logs suggest Shakturi, not Boskara, that ruled here. Perhaps our ancestors granted their allies permission to command as reward for loyal service. Final logs end suddenly. Reports of massive seismic events throughout planet.

Ancient technology advanced. Clever programmers from long ago age. Still, no match for Boskara scientists. Computer programs overwritten. Cyber protections insufficient. Defensive perimeter shut down. Boskara gain access with no loss of life.
Remnants of scientific notes uncovered. Indications this belonged to ancient Boskara Supremacy, Boskara worked in cooperation with allies, the Shaktur Axis. Base likely sector command center for Boskara military. Coordination of three fleets and multiple armies focused on conquering the malevolent Freedom Alliance, enemies who wished to take what should have belonged to Boskara. Everything belonged to Boskara, so resisting Boskara conquest is same as theft. Analysis suggests research conducted here was unusual, not at all Boskara in nature. Shakturi drive research. Insectoid minds like Boskara. Natural allies. Not surprising our ancestors allowed them to serve.
The final logs end suddenly, with reports of massive seismic disturbances across the planet.

What we have discovered is astonishing! A lost colony of Boskara, a forgotten outpost of the ancient Boskara Supremacy just as we were. A day for celebration of our oneness. And yet there is cause for concern. The message from the surface produces surprise. Alarm.
"Greetings in peace, lost siblings," says these beings. "We are the Boskara Collective. Our community strives to achieve expansion and prosperity through collaboration and harmony. You have clearly traveled far to reach us, and we look forward to hearing of your non-violent journeys among the stars."
These Boskara are confused, corrupted, diminished by time and isolation. They have forgotten what they are and so become something else, something alien. We must think. Decide. Can they be absorbed and put to work advancing our new cause of supremacy, or must they be severed like a rotting limb?

You, the inhabitants of Mikai are lost. Confused. You have forgotten what it is to be Boskara. You have been corrupted by your isolation. We will reabsorb you, make our mind, your mind. You will join us in our quest to become what we once were, what we can be again.
We feel you have much to teach us

You, the inhabitants of Mikai are lost. Confused. You have forgotten what it is to be Boskara. You have been corrupted by your isolation, and this corruption is a disease. Boskara take and consume what can be used, destroy what threatens. You threaten our unity. You have the potential to infect our society like a disease, and this cannot be tolerated.
We fear what you have become.

The message comes from the surface. "You surprise us. Confuse us. Your nature is alien to us, and yet you are Boskara. More than that, there is something in your words that sings to us, that resonates like the words of a long-forgotten whisper across the hivemind. You have expanded and you have conquered, you tell us. You have taken and consumed. It is not our way, but it is a way that sounds to usâ€¦ not wrong."
This is indeed a promising start to the integration of these outcasts. Our diplomats travel to the surface. Our scientists talk to their scientists. There is much communing, much understanding. Their past was one of isolation and hardship. They had to adapt to survive, and that adaptation led to change. Terrible change. Now they will know their true nature.
But there is more. Some of their records of the past are more complete than our own. Their stories of the Shakturi tell of terrible beings, conquerors who outmatched even the might of the Boskara Supremacy. It speaks of other hiveminds, not Boskara, that the Shakturi dominated and controlled. Could it be our ancestors did not subordinate the Shakturi but were subordinate to Shakturi? Could it be that the ancient Boskara did not make use of the Shakturi but strived to be of use to them that they might survive? These are disturbing revelations. We must think. Consider.

These pathetic things that dared to call themselves Boskara. They have fallen before our might. It is a day for mourning, not for their destruction, but that it was necessary to destroy. Far better to have rejoined lost hatchlings than to crush the weak and degenerate. No matter. Their world is ours. Their resources are our resources. Their survivors join our unity. The Boskara continue to advance.
And yet, in their records are disturbing revelations. There are tales of the Boskara and Shakturi that do not match what we have previously surmised. They speak of the Shakturi as terrible beings, conquerors who outmatched even the might of the Boskara Supremacy. They speak of non-Boskara hiveminds dominated and subsumed. Could it be our ancestors did not subordinate the Shakturi but were subordinate to them? Perhaps it is their own corrupt bias, but our historians do not believe that is so. Could it be that the ancient Boskara did not make use of the Shakturi but strived to be of use to them that they might survive? These are disturbing revelations. We must think. Consider.
Greetings, strangers. We are the Boskara Collective. Our community strives to achieve expansion and prosperity through collaboration and harmony. Will you reach out an appendage in friendship?
We embrace your friendship. We look forward to jointly exploring and learning.
You accepted our offer of friendship.
"We cannot abide those who turn their backs on friendship. Leave our space or face unpleasant consequences."
You rejected our offer of friendship.

There is an incoming communication from the pirate fleet. "Identify yourselves. We are the Independent Space League. What is your business here? Your insectoid appearance alarms us, for we have nothing but hatred for the Hive, but we detect something organized and methodical about your ships and communication - not like the Hive at all. Perhaps you have some interest in the ruins on {0}. We've found remnants insects there, and like you, they were clearly intelligent and more organized than the Hive. Who knew there were so many bugs out there!"
Insectoid ruins on planet. Perhaps ancient Boskara. Perhaps Shakturi. Worth investigating. We must respond to pirate communication.
"Yes, we have interest in ruins. We seek answer from our past."
"That's your business" the pirates reply. "Stay out of our way, and we won't have to hurt you. We'd be willing to sell you access to that planet for a reasonable fee. How does 50,000cr sound to you?"

"Your payment has cleared! We will transmit a receipt within the next 2 to 4 business cycles. By the way, the planet has a tendency to attract Vordikar. I suppose we could have mentioned that before taking your money, but we didn't feel like it. Buyer beware and all that. But I'm in a good mood today, so I'll tell you what. We won't go out of our way to help you, but if we see any Vordikar, we'll take them on."
You have purchased explorer rights from us.
"A lot of bugs out there. Maybe too many, if you catch my drift. Anyone who is not a customer is an enemy. That's how it goes in this dangerous galaxy. Wish we could have done business."
You refused our perfectly reasonable bribe.

Fascinating findings from the planet. Much here of value. This was a secret base of the Boskara Supremacy - secret from their Freedom Alliance enemies, yes, but also from their Shakturi allies. Their Shakturi "masters", or so it seems. Data here suggests all the galaxy quaked before the Shakturi, even the immensely powerful Boskara Supremacy, before whom all the galaxy had quaked prior to the Shakturi arrival. Our ancestor appears to have wondered what would happen once Freedom Alliance was eliminated. Would Boskara be like other hivemind species, made into slave?
Data does not indicate what Boskara planned, or if they dared to plan anything. Yet submission is inconceivable. We must keep looking. Keep searching.

There is an incoming communication from the pirate fleet. "Greetings unknown traveler. We are the League of Vacuum Dwellers, an independent and thriving space fleet. What brings you to our system, and what do you have to offer us to put us in a good mood?"
You respond at once. "You do not need to know who we are. What we seek here is our own concern. Trouble us at your own peril."
"You're cheeky for a nest of dirt bugs, aren't you? Still, could be worse. We worried at first you might be Hive, but your ability to make almost rational conversation says otherwise. We're thinking that you might be interested in the ruins on {0}. Those were once occupied by dirt-stomping bugs too, but the remnants are old. We're talking centuries. Maybe some long-lost nest-mates of yours? I think we could sell you explorers' rights to {0} for 50,000cr."
Smart move. Glad to see your compound eyes have taken in the situation. By the way, there's an automated defensive station orbiting the planet, so watch yourself. Or don't. Not our business.
You have purchased explorer rights from us.

"As our old saying goes, 'Those who will not engage in fair trade, are not to be numbered among friends or even friendly acquaintances.' As true today as ever. It would be unwise to turn your backs on us, dirt bugs."
You refused our perfectly reasonable bribe.

Another base, this one used by both Boskara and Shakturi to fight against the Freedom Alliance. There are suggestions here that these cowardly foes plotted a secret weapon, something that targeted Shakturi modes of travel. It seems the Shakturi used wormhole drives that were the bane of the Freedom Alliance. The Freedom Alliance, in turn, sought some means of using the wormhole drives against their enemies. Whether or not this research was successful cannot be determined here.
There is more, however. We have uncovered the location of another base occupied by both Boskara and Shakturi, this a facility dedicated to learning more about the plans of the Freedom Alliance. We must examine this place. Perhaps it will tell us more about this lost technology. Perhaps it will tell us more about how the Boskara Supremacy chose to respond to the intolerable situation of being subordinate to the Shakturi.

As we approach this planet, we receive a communication. "Warning, you are approaching a captured enemy base, now overseen by the Ackdarians on behalf of the Freedom Alliance. This is an advance force, awaiting reinforcement. I repeat, we are awaiting reinforcements, which we expect to arrive within days. If you are a member of the Freedom Alliance, present your appropriate security code. Otherwise, countermeasures will be activated. You have been warned."
Unsettling. Surprising. It seems this Freedom Alliance actually achieved a victory over the Boskara and Shakturi. Ancient message from long ago. Vanguard forces awaiting reinforcements for centuries. Haunting. Yet good news, for it suggests Boskara base below might remain intact. We must investigate and find out further.
For our response we can attempt to decieve the sentries or we can attempt to hack them.

Records here have decayed with time. Data banks corroded, but still intact. Not yet accessed by Freedom Alliance captors. Much to be learned. The Shakturi frightened our ancestors with their might and technology. Shakturi could eventually conquer all, even Boskara. Shakturi modes of travel could destroy space itself. Becoming too destructive, even for Boskara. Our ancestors were cautious. Careful. Corroded data suggests a previous effort to defeat Shakturi by another species. This effort was unsuccessful. Our ancestors were tasked with much of the punishment. A terrible lesson, but also instructional. There is information on a Boskara Research Facility. Implications. Hints. This may be where Boskara planned their own victory against all. We must investigate.

Warning, you are approaching a captured enemy base, now overseen by the Ackdarians on behalf of the Freedom Alliance. This is an advance force, awaiting reinforcement. I repeat, we are awaiting reinforcements, which we expect to arrive within days. If you are a member of the Freedom Alliance, present your appropriate security code. Otherwise, countermeasures will be activated. You have been warned. Present your security clearance or face hostile action.

The databanks have been damaged and corroded with time, but Records make clear this was once a Boskara base, conquered by the Freedom Alliance during the closing days of the Shakturi war. We were able to glean some details about military research conducted by the Boskara. Perhaps it is something we can use.

"We are of the Freedom Alliance," you tell the sentries.
"That is unconfirmed. Please provide appropriate access code."
"Many years have passed since you were last provided appropriate access code," you answer. "We have the correct codes, but you do not. It is you who cannot prove your authority to guard a Freedom Alliance conquest."
The sentry is silent for a long time. Finally, you hear, "Under the circumstances, it has been determined prudent to grant you access."

Our science team has completed its research into ancient technology. Even weak minds of Freedom Alliance were advanced. Clever. Protective systems challenging for even greatest of Boskara minds. Still no challenge too great for Boskara. Scientists infiltrate planetary defensive systems.
Boskara scientists begin shutting down Freedom Alliance defenses, but enemy systems, though ancient, activate. Attempt to lock out Boskara scientists. Two of the three defensive bases are neutralized before no further infiltration possible.
The opposing forces will now be severely weakened. This ancient Freedom Alliance would surely have fallen more quickly had it faced today's Boskara.
Interesting. Damaged world. Detect ruins. Small population. Boskara.

"You are unknown to us. You are strangers. You are not of the Guardians.
We are the Guardians, placed here by Boskara Supremacy for our purpose. Our purpose has been forgotten. Only fragments remain. We know only those who belong may approach. We detect you are Boskara, but are you the right Boskara or the wrong Boskara? This is what we must know."

These Guardians are troubling. How can there have been right Boskara and wrong Boskara in the time of the Supremacy. Surely there was one Supremacy, united by common mind, common purpose. This suggestion of schism is confusing.

"We are the Guardians. You must withdraw or prove your belonging. Are you right Boskara or wrong Boskara?"
These Guardians want to know who is true enemy of Boskara. Who presents existential threat to Boskara. We must transmit answer.
GameEventAction.ChoiceButtonText: Yes, we are the right Boskara.
There is only one Boskara, and you must take your place in the hive.

GameEventAction.Description: "We are the Guardians. You are wrong Boskara. We will destroy you."
You are not the right Boskara

"We are the Guardians. It is not enough to say you are right Boskara. You must prove you are right Boskara. You must have the knowledge of right Boskara. You must know true enemy of Boskara. You must know who Boskara must survive if Boskara are to continue."
These Guardians want to know who is true enemy of Boskara. Who presents existential threat to Boskara. We must transmit answer.
"We are the Guardians. You have provided correct answer. We are standing down. This base is now in the hands of Right Boskara. Our mission is, at long last, complete."

Sad remnants of lost Boskara have allowed us access. They can be reabsorbed into Boskara hivemind. Now our scientists may explore this base. We shall see what there is to be discovered. We hope for many answers.

GameEventAction.GeneratedItemName: Secret Boskara Research Facility Reward A (Boskara)

GameEvent.Name: Secret Boskara Research Facility Reward A (Boskara)

GameEventAction.Description:
Much is decayed here. Guardians absorbed now into hive, but their knowledge is fragmentary. Corrupted.
It is clear now that this was secret Boskara facility. Secret from Shakturi. It is why facility was cut off, so plotting would not be revealed to Shakturi. Boskara Supremacy hated Freedom Alliance but did not trust Shakturi. Corruption of other species with hive minds alarming. Those hive minds enslaved. Only Boskara were free. But can they be free when they acted out of fear? Boskara plotted, but outcome still unknown.
Important revelation. Location of Boskara homeworld discovered! Origin of our hive can now be explored. This place may hold the answers to our past... and to our future.

Guardians destroyed. World now belong to Boskara. There is only one, unified Boskara. Ancient data corrupted and decayed, but likely this was secret Boskara facility. Secret from Shakturi. Perhaps this is why facility was cut off, so plotting would not be revealed to Shakturi. Boskara Supremacy hated Freedom Alliance but did not trust Shakturi. Corruption of other species with hive minds alarming. Those hive minds enslaved. Only Boskara were free. But can they be free when they acted out of fear? Boskara plotted, but outcome still unknown.
But important revelation. Location of Boskara homeworld discovered! Origin of our hive can now be explored. This place may hold the answers to our past - and to our future.

"We are the Guardians, placed here by Boskara Supremacy for our purpose. Our purpose has been forgotten. Only fragments remain. We know only those who belong may approach. We detect you are not Boskara. You do not have permission to approach."
You are not the Boskara Supremacy

We are the Hive. We consume. You are to be consumed, You are food. We destroy. The voices drive us on to consume, to make ready for Great Ones. All but Great Ones are to be consumed. Prepare to be consumed by the Hive.

At last on ancient soil of the homeworld. Destruction and devastation. Little remains, but enough to understand. Freedom Alliance used terrible device. Struck before Boskara even had a plan to overthrow Shakturi. Space itself damaged. The storms we have seen come from this time. Shakturi vanquished, but at price. Galaxy thrown into chaos. Technology lost. Great civilizations brought low.
Of the hivemind beings, only Boskara survive with minds intact because Boskara not part of Shakturi hivemind. Others go mad without Shakturi guidance. Become dreaded Hive.
Many answers, and yet troubling questions. Hive abominations spoke of the voices. Of the Great Ones. Could some other hivemind unknown to Boskara be reaching out to them. Or worse, could Shakturi somehow, from some place, be speaking to Hive? Could they return to once again make Boskara subordinate?
Boskara must be ready. The Boskara Supremacy was brought low. The new Boskara civilization must not allow itself to be destroyed.
The artifacts we have found in the ruins may help. It seems some of our scientists were attempting to create a safer version of their powerful hyperdrives. The other seems to be a weapon they were working on, powerful enough to bring down even Shakturi ships.

The world lies in ruins, but this was certainly the home of the ancient Boskara Supremacy. The sought to save themselves by siding with the Shakturi. It seems their efforts earned them nothing but destruction. Our efforts, on the other hand, have been far more profitable.

Our explorers have scented a remarkable discovery. Hidden deep underground on {0} is the outer hull of what we believe to be an ancient spacecraft. What is it? Where did it come from? Is it something alien and unfathomable, which might somehow harm or corrupt our people? The unknown is always repulsive, and yet perhaps there is something to be learned from this wreckage. Retrieving this artefact intact will be neither easy nor inexpensive, but as the old saying goes, sometimes you must spend credits to make credits. A safer course, however, might be to scrap it, using its constituent parts to further our own exploration efforts.

With diligent patience and meticulous planning, our brilliant engineers have managed to dislodge this ship from the rocky vault that has encased it these long centuries. The evidence now confirms our suspicions: the ship was, indeed, designed by, and for, ancient Haakonish explorers. Legends tell of a glorious Haakonish trade empire that once spanned the stars, and surely this is proof. Fragmentary logs are written in a language that is difficult to understand, likely a form of ancient Haakonish. Our scientists were able to glean that the ship had already visited several other locations in this system in its search for a "safe haven." Quite interesting, but also disturbing. A safe haven from what? What is out there in the vast expanse of space? We must assume anything we encounter is a threat.
A polymer source was found.

As the old saying goes, "See the unknown, destroy the unknown." Our engineers planted explosives, and reduced the offensive relic to its constituent parts. This has turned to be both intelligent and lucrative. How often those two virtues align! The materials we gained from this undertaking will aid us in our exploration and our quest for financial glory.

We have discovered an ancient spacecraft on {0}. This vessel is of an advanced design, but in very poor shape. Our surveys suggest that there are only portions of the ship intact, yet some of those fragments are larger than the earlier derelict ship we discovered.
Is it Haakonish or alien? Is this, perhaps, the remnants of an ancient invasion fleet, and if such an invasion was attempted, could it happen again? Whatever that ship contains could be interesting and valuable, and yet the knowledge of an advanced and threatening alien species could agitate the population. Already there are rumors circulating of the discovery, and they will be difficult to silence.

Our archeologists and engineers have applied themselves to uncovering the crashed vessel. The discoveries are equal parts troubling and intriguing. The wreckage appears to be a colony ship, carrying tens of thousands of Haakonish settlers, heading to this system. It clearly did not make it, though we must assume others did or there would be no Haakonish civilization in {1}.
The strange language of the logs, and their damaged condition, present obstacles to interpretation, but it is clear that these Haakonish were fleeing hostile aliens and a galaxy-spanning cataclysm of some sort. What could have been so terrible that it would drive these Haakonish away from their homes and business and into the unknown? Is that danger still out there?
The discovery of this lost ship has caused great concern on the homeworld. Many doubt that it makes financial sense to venture out into the unknown where we might encounter the very dangers and uncertainty that we now know our ancestors fled. Still, we cannot vomit up knowledge the way we would an unsatisfactory meal. We have made our choice, and now we will have to learn how to profit from it.
And the profiting has begun already. We have gained significant knowledge of colonization technology from the wreckage of this ship. More than that, we have discovered a curious artifact which will aid us with with trade should we encounter any inevitably inferior aliens.

All evidence of this ship has been buried deep where it will never be found. On the homeworld, we are countering the rumors with media stories, public broadcasts, and text attached to merchandise coupons, all which refute that such a ship ever existed. And the public relations campaign is working! The people seem soothed and content. We are still alone in the universe, they tell themselves. Should they ever learn otherwise, well, we shall deal with that when and if it happens.

May pleasing odors fill your nostrils, lost siblings! We see you have unshackled yourselves from a life of gravity and unfiltered air! We are the Clan of Superiority. Once we were soil-pounders like you, but now we are free. Our ancestors were early offworld miners who stumbled upon some ancient ship technology. That allowed us to leave our home system and the limiting tether of land and sky. You inferiors still cling to the old way. The Clan of Superiority is unbound and prosperous. Still, you are Haakonish and not unlike us. We will consider trading with you if you are willing to invest in our mutual prosperity. It is an opportunity you should not miss! If you reject us, you are no Haakonish, but rather filth to be expelled into vacuum, and we will not countenance your presence in our space.

The news of these Haakonish space-dwellers has caused confusion and anxiety on the homeworld. They were once Haakonish, once like us, but they have become something strange and uncanny. Something alien. It is disturbing. And yet they know things we do not, have developed technology that is unfamiliar to us. And they speak of trade and opportunities, so the Haakonish heart still beats within their chest cavities. A closer relationship with them will make our people unhappy, yet the only alternative appears to be war.

GameEventAction.ChoiceButtonText: Declare these strangers to be our enemies

GameEventAction.Description: A wise investment, which is proof of your true Haakonish nature. We are proud to call you siblings. Speak to our merchants about purchasing fashionable licensed Clan of Superiority apparel. We will share with you some of what we have learned in our travels, and our commerce shall be your commerce. The future looks prosperous, my siblings.
You invested in us

The truth has been revealed, soil-stompers! Your value has decreased while you've been clinging to your precious planet. We have divested from your inferior ways, and we will not be corrupted by your gravity-bound decadence. From this day forward, you are the enemies of the Clan of Superiority, and you will be treated as such. Stay out of our space, non-siblings.
You cling to your inferior ways

They were not an insignificant enemy for some part of them remained Haakonish, but they were no match for our industriousness and the greed that drives us to achieve victory. We scented their weakness and tasted their defeat, and now their misbegotten way of life has fallen into bankruptcy. It always had to be this way.
War eats credits, and there is always the opportunity cost of what could have been achieved if those credits had been invested elsewhere, and yet this venture was not unprofitable. We have learned something of their ways and discovered the secrets of this system. We have also plundered their wealth and emptied their storehouses. At home the people cheer the purifying of our species. All in all, a good deal.

This is a terrible and frightening day! We have discovered a derelict spaceship of non-Haakonish design, containing living aliens. Their engines are damaged and long-range communications are out, but we have nevertheless made preliminary contact with them. They say they are of a race calling themselves the humans. They are frighteningly ugly, and their intellectual capacity is clearly limited, but they are nevertheless spacefaring aliens. Our hope that we would be alone in the universe is dashed forever.
The aliens speak a garbled and primitive language, but our linguists believe they are asking for help. News of this ship and its plight have sparked a debate on the homeworld. Do we offer these creatures assistance, and thereby help a potential rival, or do we question the aliens, study their language, and then destroy them?
GameEventAction.ChoiceButtonText: Learn the language & destroy the ship 5,000cr
Learn the language & help the aliens 10,000cr

GameEventAction.Description:
In some ways this operation has gone well. In other ways, it went poorly.
On the profits side of the ledger, our brilliant scientists were able to crack the code of their simplistic language. Consequently we were able to, let us say, encourage the creatures to tell us about their planet and culture. Having learned all they had to tell us, we had the creatures destroyed. Our engineers then took their ship apart. Their records suggest there may be even more kinds of aliens out there than these creatures, and perhaps encountering other species is inevitable. In the meantime, our people cheer at the news that this threat has been eliminated.
On the loss side of the ledger, the aliens were able to repair their communications systems shortly before we boarded their vessel. We believe they contacted their homeworld and presented our violent occupation of their ship in an unflattering light.
You destroyed our lost ship

We have rescued the aliens and our scientists have gone to work cracking the code of their primitive language. These creatures say they are humans, and they have provided us with the location of their homeworld. Odd as it may seem, they claim they take pleasure in meeting other aliens. They even responded warmly to the idea of trading with us. Most curious. These creatures are unpleasant to look at, their language is painful to our ears, and their ideas are simple and childlike, but they also have an innate love of commerce and cuisine. Strange to find Haakonish values in beings so unHaakonish. Back home, our people are angry that the aliens were permitted to live, but the outrage is not as bad as some had predicted.
The aliens have allowed our engineers to aid in repairing their ship. Such fools! They have no idea we are examining their technology for what we can steal. It is a wonder such stupid creatures were able to discover the secrets of space travel in the first place.
You assisted our lost ship

You've encountered what appears to be a derelict transport ship. It is attempting to make contact with you.
"Greetings, strangers. We mean no harm. We are a trading vessel suffering engine failure. Can you offer assistance?"
Thank you, strangers! We are forever in your debt. Know that the people of our homeworld will welcome you as friends.
You assisted our lost ship
The ship continues to drift. Perhaps the beings on board will be rescued by someone else. Perhaps they'll die. The galaxy can be a cruel place.

Ah, the Haakonish. We know of you from our ancient records. You are disreputable in trade and dishonorable in diplomacy. Perhaps the centuries have changed your kind, but we doubt it. We suggest you leave our system, as we have no interest in a relationship.

Their dislike of the alien and unfamiliar speaks well of these creatures, and their desire to remain isolated is honorable. A mutual disdain would be acceptable if they did not know something of our past. Any information they have might be valuable to us. Perhaps there is a way, for, as it was said in our grandparents' time, there is no problem too large to be solved with money. An investment in diplomacy might help to change their minds, though that will make our patriotically xenophobic people unhappy. Alternatively, we might invest in stealing their technology to make ourselves superior. Then we shall never have to concern ourselves with what they think of us.

Our diplomats are well trained in filling the right nostrils with sweet fragrances. A bribe here, a flattering word there, is all it takes. A few forged documents recounting fabricated incidents in the past can convince these Ackdarians that our ways are more similar to their ways than they first believed.
"We put no faith in you, Haakonish," they tell us. "Not yet. An improvement in relations will have to be earned. In the meantime, we will make a gesture of goodwill by telling you that we have ancient legends of your kind. We know there was once a galaxy span trade consortium of Haakonish. They were not well trusted. Some documents refer to them as self-serving betrayers in a great galactic war. One more reason to be cautious around you, but perhaps time has changed you. Perhaps the legends are wrong. Your actions now, rather than stories from our past, will guide us."

Our clever Haakonish spies have infiltrated the aliens' world. We have used bribery to recruit agents. Through our clever means, we have learned secrets of their technology. Back home, the discovery of a space-faring species has inspired our people to work harder and research faster. A glorious new competitive air fills the nostrils of the Haakonish. Let the aliens despise us. They shall learn which species is superior.

We shall have to decide if we want to make these aliens our partners or our enemies, but at least they are not so hostile as they were before. Meanwhile, the discovery of a space-faring species has inspired the people at home to work harder and research faster. A new air of competition fills the nostrils of the Haakonish.
We may have misjudged you
We suspect you of spying on us

Everywhere on this ravaged world we find evidence of ancient Haakonish habitation. No soil can be uncovered, or wilderness traversed, without encountering decayed devices, scattered bones and ruined buildings - some which suggest a society more prosperous and impressive than even that of our homeworld. There can be no doubt that this was once a thriving Haakonish world with a sizable population. It may be well worth our time to investigate further, to learn what we can from the past, and yet knowledge of a thriving world so destroyed may agitate our people.

Teams of historians and archeologists have begun investigating the ruins of this world. The evidence is clear that {0} was merely one thriving outpost in the fabulously wealthy Haakonish Star Guild. Records indicate a great war, however, which the Haakonish wisely wished no part of. Instead, showing the wisdom of our people, they sought to profit from the death and destruction of others. All evidence suggests that this was no ordinary war, however. An invading force we believed were called the Shakturi were evidently formidable conquerors. War makes for good business, yes, but refugees are a drain upon any economy, and the Shakturi produced far too many of those. One disturbing account speaks of the Shakturi having conquered "half the galaxy." Monopolies are to be admired, yes, but only when in Haakonish hands.
Most troubling of all, we believe that the civilization on this world ended quite suddenly in unimaginable seismic and volcanic destruction. It is difficult to imagine what could cause such a disaster. It is even more difficult to imagine how a planet ruled by Haakonish could not foresee and avoid it.
We have only begun to uncover all this world has to offer, however. It may be wise to invest even further in archeological expeditions.

We will conceal from the public everything we have learned about this world, but first we will scour it for any information or materials we can use. If there is something here from which we might gain, we must use it.

We have managed to recover some resources of this fallen world, and, inevitably, some knowledge of ancient history was discovered along the way. It seems this world was once a thriving outpost of the Haakonish Star Guild, which attempted to profit during a time of great war, led by invaders called Shakturi. There is, of course, no better time to profit than during war, but it seems this conflict may have caused so much destruction that it made it impossible even for the Haakonish to benefit. The Star Guild traded with both sides, which is the correct thing to do, but some records suggest this sound business practice may have been discovered and interpreted as some as treachery.

This world is damaged, and once great buildings are now no more than rubble. There is evidence it was once a thriving outpost of the Ancient Haakonish Star Guild. It may well be worthwhile to excavate the ruins, but doing so will be costly.

This has proved to be a worthwhile expedition. You have discovered an ancient monolithic data storage device, weathered but functional. The ancient Haakonish appear to have stored a significant portion of their cultural works on the subjects of preparing and eating fine food as well as artifice and subterfuge. The Haakonish who wrote these works found that through the intersection of those two arts, they could find exploitable weaknesses in other inferior cultures through the analysis of their culinary preferences and customs. Throughout these works, the superiority of Haakonish gastronomy, partly due to their superior biology, is often and repeatedly asserted as self-evident. Perhaps most interesting, many of the finest Haakonish dishes make use of Korrabian Spice and several ancient locations where it may perhaps still be found are recorded herein.
Let the past remained buried. Our future lies elsewhere.

The news has reverberated throughout our culture. Another competitor in the galactic marketplace, and this one far stronger and more ambitious than any isolated worlds or wandering vacuum dwellers we've encountered already. These aliens are by no means our superiors, and yet it is possible - merely possible, hardly certain - for them to claim the galaxy for their own. The stars and their worlds should be exploited by the Haakonish, and it is our destiny use the galaxy as we wish, but the distant past has shown us that Haakonish superiority is not always enough.
Among our people there have been riots, suicides, even hunger strikes. The quarterly profit projections are enough to make any cold-blooded being weep with sorrow. Yet what can we do? We cannot plug our nostrils and hope for the best. Our competitors will not go away. We must face this challenge as a strong and determined people.

The Haakonish were once the greatest traders in the galaxy, and they will be again. Billboards, broadcasts, data-encoded pheromone mists - they all spread the word. We must remind people of their innate superiority at every turn. We have researched the culture of these {3} and have shown them to be inferior, degenerate, and possessing a pathetic sense of smell. Their food is tasteless and badly prepared. How can we question our ultimate triumph when these are our rivals? The Haakonish are the greatest competitors in the universe, and we will make these primitive aliens our subordinates.

What is the greatest of Haakonish virtues? Our competitive spirit! We cannot allow ourselves to be demoralized by the appearance of a rival. No, we must embrace the struggle to triumph and be inspired by it. The Haakonish people do not cower, they compete. Only by being better, more advanced, more cut-throat, can we show what we truly are. That is the way forward! Our program of inspiration and incentives will create an environment of innovation and entrepreneurship such as has never before been seen.

All signs indicate this was once an outpost of the ancient Haakonish Star Guild, the glorious trade empire of our ancestors. They wisely defended it against their many competitors and rivals, placing defensive stations in orbits and defensive bases in key positions on the surface. And yet we must know what secrets are buried here. There may also be riches and trade goods, and surely the ones who came before us would want their descendants to inherit their wealth.

Our ancestors were clever, but so are we, and we have learned much by apprenticing ourselves to the knowledge of our forebears. Haakonish scientists were able to gain access to the planetary defense computer systems, still partially active after all these years, and begin the process of powering down the automated systems. Of course, our ingenious Haakonish ancestors had safeguards against such infiltrations, but those safeguards have also decayed over the centuries. We were able to neutralize two of the stations and two of the bases. Our soldiers, each fighting for the bonuses that go to the successful, will take care of the rest.

Life is expensive, as the old saying goes, which is why the families of fallen soldiers must be compensated out of their commanders' pockets. This provides a strong incentive not to waste lives needlessly. Our troops have landed upon the surface.
Now that the way is clear, we have gone through the fragmentary logs of the planetary bases. Once this was a thriving outpost of the Haakonish Star Guild, but the galaxy was thrown into chaos by the invasion of the Shakturi who - if we are reading these records correctly - invaded from outside the galaxy itself. Astonishing. Their ships traveled using an advanced wormhole-based technology that was both previously unknown. It use appears to have caused damage to the fabric of space itself, though the records on this are unclear. The Haakonish sought to counter the Shakturi with the development of a gravitic weapon. Recordings end suddenly, though there is mention of planet-wide seismic devastation.
Standing against the Shakturi were an organization with the disturbing name "Freedom Alliance." This name suggests weakness, but they evidently proved to be worthy adversaries, though their cause was doomed. The Haakonish did what we always do and traded with both sides.
In the planetary bases we have discovered some interesting secrets of ancient Haakonish military research as well as the location of another base.

With the planetary defenses neutralized, our scientists have begun going through base logs. They are damaged and incomplete, but there is still a great deal to be learned.
Once this was a thriving outpost of the Haakonish Star Guild, but the galaxy was thrown into chaos by the invasion of the Shakturi who - if we are reading these records correctly - invaded from outside the galaxy itself. Astonishing. Their ships traveled using an advanced wormhole technology that was both previously unknown and damaging to the fabric of space itself. Perhaps this explains some of the instability and anomalies we encounter in the galaxy today. The logs end with mention of planet-wide seismic devastation
Standing against the Shakturi were an organization called the "Freedom Alliance." The name suggests weakness, but evidently, they proved worthy adversaries, though their cause was doomed. The Haakonish did what we always do and traded with both sides, even while seeking to counter the Shakturi with some sort of gravitic weapon.
In the planetary bases we have discovered some interesting secrets of ancient Haakonish science as well as the location of another base.
We have detected the debris from orbital defense stations near this planet. There may be other dangers. Proceeding with caution would be wise.
There are three defense stations orbiting this world. They appear to be ancient and damaged, but they are powering up!

The ruins here reveal the remnants of what was clearly a great trade hub, filled with vast warehouses, depots, and entrepots, most of which have fallen into ruin. We have discovered a central facility that is partially intact. It contains computer systems our scientists believe to be operational, and there is also an entrance to a vast storehouse, which likely contains valuable resources. The massive seismic damage to the planet makes any sort of retrieval both complicated and dangerous. Initial surveys indicate it should be possible to retrieve either one of these. Accessing both may also be possible, but far more expensive. We must choose carefully how we wish to invest.
Which one should we invest in?

We have been able to stabilize the surrounding structure and make our way into the central computer core, where our most brilliant minds have scented out the means of accessing such data as is still available. Much like other former Haakonish worlds we've visited, this one seems to have been destroyed by sudden and powerful seismic activity. All evidence suggests the planetwide destruction was caused by the Shakturi. It seems they invaded this galaxy, bent on conquest for its own sake. Their wormhole drives made them difficult to track and guard against, and we have again seen that they damaged the fabric of space.
Our ancestors traded with the Shakturi, as was wise, but it became apparent that when these invaders defeated the Freedom Alliance, they would turn on those who remained. For that reason, the Haakonish, even while doing business with the Shakturi, bravely worked in secret to defeat them with a gravitic device when the time was right. The deception and treachery of our ancestors is remarkable.
The computer banks have revealed other valuable technological secrets to us, and we now believe we know the location of the lost Haakonish homeworld. It seems to have been hidden from the Shakturi by means of a granitic stealth technology, keeping our people safe while the rest of the galaxy fled in terror.

We have been able to stabilize the surrounding structure and make our way into the central storage facilities, where we have discovered a treasure trove of valuable material. Most fortunately, we have also discovered some logs which reveal to us a great deal about the final days of this planet. It was destroyed by massive seismic upheaval, much like other Haakonish worlds we've encountered.
We've learned that our ancestors traded with the Shakturi, as was wise, but it became apparent that when these invaders defeated the Freedom Alliance, which fought against them, they would turn on any who remained. For that reason, the Haakonish, even while doing business with the Shakturi, bravely worked in secret to defeat them with a gravitic weapon that targeted the invaders' wormhole drives. The deception and treachery of our ancestors is truly a wonderful to thing to learn of.
The records here also reveal the location of the lost Haakonish capital. It seems to have been hidden from the Shakturi by means of a granitic stealth technology, keeping our people safe while the rest of the galaxy fled in terror.

Like other Haakonish worlds we've found, this one was destroyed by massive seismic activity, but we have been able to stabilize both structures. In the central computer core, our most brilliant minds have scented out the means of accessing such data as is still available. We have learned that the invaders of this Galaxy, the Shakturi Axis, pursued conquest for its own sake. Their wormhole drives, allowed for them to always maintain the element of surprise in their attacks, destroying not only the worlds they encountered, but tearing holes in space itself.
Other teams were able to stabilize the surrounding structure and make our way into the central storage facilities, where we have discovered a treasure trove of valuable material. Most fortunately, we have also discovered some logs which reveal to us a great deal about the final days of this planet.
In both locations, we have learned much about the past. Our ancestors traded with the Shakturi, as was wise, but it became apparent that when these invaders defeated the Freedom Alliance, which fought against them, they would turn on those who remained. For that reason, the Haakonish, even while doing business with the Shakturi, bravely worked in secret to defeat them with a gravitic weapon. The deception and treachery of our ancestors is truly a wonderful to thing to learn of.
The computer banks have revealed other valuable technological secrets to us, and we now believe we know the location of the lost Haakonish homeworld. It seems to have been hidden from the Shakturi by means of a granitic stealth technology, keeping our people safe while the rest of the galaxy fled in terror.

We have examined recovered records on Alliance ships that accuse the Haakonish of treachery, all for the crime of wanting to protect our own wealth. No, the Haakonish did not behave dishonorably. Our people sold to customers, be they Freedom Alliance or Shakturi Axis. That much is clear. So little respect these Freedom Alliance had for those who would lie to save their own hides.
It seems the Haakonish were too clever for their enemies. The gravitic weapon they developed were deployed against the Shakturi, whose violence was incompatible with long-term profits. Something went wrong, however. Surviving data indicates that the Freedom Alliance had a weapon of their own. Perhaps its effects clashed with the effects of the Haakonish weapon. The Freedom Alliance were fools for not offering to sell their secrets to the Haakonish. The resulting chaos could have been avoided. The Haakonish world could have been saved, and the Haakonish Star Guild might have reigned supreme all these centuries.
Now because of the mistakes of small-minded aliens, we have been forced to build again, to reach for mastery again. The knowledge we gain from examining this wreckage, from the catastrophe brought about by other species not trusting in the Haakonish, will help us lead away. Given our cleverness, and the relative stupidity of other species, our ultimate mastery is assured.

Our exploration of what remains of this planet makes it clear that this was likely an ancient Haakonish stronghold, perhaps even their homeworld. Now all lies in ruins. Or almost all. We have uncovered powerful ancient technology. Reaching this world was not easy, but it was well worth the effort

We've encountered a vast field of destruction. There are fragmentary remnants of ancient ships, an unfathomable number. The evidence seems to suggest they were from species of the Freedom Alliance. It is hard to imagine what could have destroyed a fleet so large.

There is so much destruction. So much waste. All of these Haakonish ships destroyed. This must be the remnants of our people's great fleet, but what could have happened to it? All evidence suggests that they should have been hidden and safe from this war. It seems we are mistaken. Or they were.

This field of destroyed ships was once a fleet of an almost unimaginable number. Some here we recognize as Boskara, but there are parts of others of a kind we have not encountered before, but our scientists speculate that these must be Shakturi vessels. They terrorized the entire galaxy, and yet they were crushed. It seems that even the Shakturi were capable of overextending themselves.

We've encountered a vast field of destruction. There are fragmentary remnants of ancient ships, an unfathomable number. The evidence seems to suggest they were from species of the Freedom Alliance, fighting in the ancient war against the Shakturi. It is hard to imagine what could have destroyed a fleet so large.
So much debris, destruction. The fragments here are mainly of Haakonish ships. Perhaps this is their ancient homeworld we approach.
